instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5v no ppbus
threads.message:
hello got this with 0V on ppbus g3h not shorted. 5v 1.87amp on all ports
mess here, previously all chips got  correct ldo voltage including 1v1 ldo on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
so i checked parts on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>/<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>/ theres no short circuit on this part.
followed from my previous post [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/solved-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-power-no-1v1-ldo.61493/[/URL]
replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>/<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> just trying my luck here. this part also did from other shops.
still no luck  . after this suddenly <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>/4200 this side my usbC meter is looping 1v1ldo still present also looping.
which is UB300/400 not looping (stable 5.19v 1.36amp) this time ub400 missing 1v1ldo after i replaced twice ub400 1v1ldo still not present
then wonder whats wrong. so i test ldo1v1 on ub300also missing so i replaced ub300 now both ub300/400 have 1v1ldo but also now looping/restarting same as
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>/4200.
 i didnt see any short/leaks on all related component,

voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> ok

<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>
pin1 7.8v
pin2 4.8v
pin3 3.4v
pin8 4.8v
pin9 1.0v
pin10 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5v no ppbus
threads.message:
You've meant to say <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> instead of <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, I suppose.

Don't waste time with <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> if already got correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Now the 4 CD3215s get 1V1 LDO and restarting?
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils.
What is exact diode mode reading at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5v no ppbus
threads.message:
forgot to mentioned <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 1.4v something before.

Now the 4 CD3215s get 1V1 LDO and restarting? YES


no short on bigcoils except this which is normal.
L7430/20/10 0.003
L7210/20 0.006
L7270/60 0.070

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.400 0.1V

threads.message:
If a good battery is connected, USB-C ports still 5V and restart?
What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery?

threads.message: with good battery usb c 20v still restart this time restarting more faster.

Any reaction pressing power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5v no ppbus
threads.message:
measure continuity to ground at LB150 and L2950.

if you have a value on the multimeter, remove that coil and test the 20v rise

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5v no ppbus
threads.message:
sorry [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 11v with battery

[USER=34050]@Mac Tech[/USER]   LB150 and L2950 diode to ground 0.260 
tried removed this 2 coils still same stock 5v and restarting..

Did you note voltage pulse at some big coils?
Especially just before restarts...
